content: The "Coordinated Recovery Initiative for Babies Act of 2014" or the "CRIB Act of 2014" focuses on the identification, treatment, and surveillance of neonatal abstinence syndrome. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to identify effective methods for treating infants with neonatal abstinence syndrome, barriers to implementing best practices, and circumstances requiring specialized care. The Secretary will convene an advisory panel to compile best practices for identifying and treating neonatal abstinence syndrome, assessing existing surveillance measures, and identifying areas needing further study. The Secretary, with the advice of the Panel, updates the list of best practices for neonatal abstinence syndrome every 2 years. The Panel consists of 19 medical professionals representing various organizations. The Secretary, advised by a Panel of 19 medical professionals from various organizations, updates best practices for neonatal abstinence syndrome every 2 years. Key organizations represented on the Panel include The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, The American Hospital Association, The American Medical Association, The American Nurses Association, The American Pharmacists Association, The American Public Health Association, The American Society for Addiction Medicine, The American Society of Anesthesiologists, The Association of State and Territorial Health Professionals, The Association of Women's Health, Obstetric, and Neonatal Nurses, The Children's Hospital Association, The National Association of Medicaid Directors, and The National Association of Nurse Practitioners in Women's Health. The Secretary will provide administrative support to the Panel for identifying and treating neonatal abstinence syndrome. Within 12 months of the Act's enactment, the Secretary will compile best practices and develop a coordination plan. Develop and implement a plan for coordinating and enhancing public health surveillance of neonatal abstinence syndrome, including identifying necessary data, addressing gaps in current surveillance, providing recommendations to states for data collection, and designating a coordinating agency within the Department. The Department will coordinate data on neonatal abstinence syndrome and submit a report to Congress within 18 months. The report will address causes, identification, treatment, prevalence, and effects of neonatal abstinence syndrome, as well as public health issues that require further study. The Secretary will disseminate best practices through various channels, including posting them on the public Internet. The Secretary will periodically review best practices every 2 years to ensure they are up-to-date and consult with the medical community. When designating an appropriate agency within the Department, factors such as resources, expertise, and capability for public health programs will be considered.
